article: Mrs Amatuli was my teacher in the fourth grade. One day at lunch time, Mrs Amatuli asked me if she could _ my sandwiches. She explained that I could use the money to buy a _ lunch from the cafeteria . I was _ . I never bought my lunch at the cafeteria. It was _ expensive for my family, and I always carried my lunch and brought the bag back home to _ again the next day. You can understand my _ when I had the opportunity to buy a hot lunch. Kids always _ about the cafeteria food but I was very _ of them. When we _ lunch that day, Mrs Amatuli took me aside and said she wanted to _ why she had bought my sandwiches. I really didn't care why, _ it gave me a few minutes of her precious _ so I was very quiet as she explained. You _ , she was a Catholic and she told me that Catholics didn't eat red meat on Fridays--they ate _ on Fridays. Oh, I couldn't _ to get home and tell my Mom that from then on I wanted fish on Fridays. _ my Mom understood why, she gladly fixed fish for me on Fridays. From then on, every Friday I could get in _ with the rest of the kids for a hot lunch. I didn't care how many of the kids complained about the cafeteria food--it _ great to me! I realize now that Mrs Amatuli _ have fixed herself a fish sandwich on Fridays. She bought my sandwiches because she saw a little girl who was pleased over the simple _ of having a hot lunch.
